class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Flife%20sciences%2Four%20insights%2Fbetter%20data%20for%20better%20therapies%20the%20case%20for%20building%20health%20data%20platforms%2Fbetter-data-for-better-therapies-the-case-for-building-health-data-platforms_final.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="better-data-for-better-therapies-the-case-for-building-health-data-platforms_final" data-layer-report-name="better-data-for-better-therapies-the-case-for-building-health-data-platforms_final>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (9 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>The past decade</strong> has seen an important and, for many patients, a life-changing rise in the number of innovative new drugs reaching the market to treat diseases such as multiple sclerosis, malaria, and subtypes of certain cancers (such as melanoma or leukemia). In the United States, the Food and Drug Administration approved an average of 41 new molecular entities (including biologic license applications) each year from 2011 to 2020—almost double the number in the previous decade.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="40c74a13-00d8-41a5-b2ab-3c2bc957469c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="40c74a13-00d8-41a5-b2ab-3c2bc957469c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Asher Mullard, “2020 FDA drug approvals,” <em>Nature Reviews Drug Discovery</em>, February 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Despite the immense costs of such achievements,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="04558ad3-eb09-489f-9fe6-6f7246697986"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="04558ad3-eb09-489f-9fe6-6f7246697986" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Asher Mullard, “New drugs cost US $2.6 billion to develop,” <em>Nature Reviews Drug Discovery</em>, December 1, 2014.</span></span></span></a></span> biopharmaceutical researchers have not yet uncovered a universal, systematic approach to generate many more breakthroughs or predict which interventions will work for which patients.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>A major barrier is the daunting challenge of understanding the multifactorial nature of many diseases coupled with the vast set of variables in therapy design. Very few diseases, such as cystic fibrosis, are linked to variants in single genes. Drug development therefore tends to rely on a reductionist, hypothesis-driven approach that narrows the focus to individual cell types or pathways. Focused assays often based on partial information or informed by animal models that never perfectly reflect human disease then attempt to identify single molecules that will benefit patients. Inevitably, that approach can be both slow and prone to bias, and most breakthroughs are serendipitous rather than systematic, as companies are largely relying on imperfect preclinical models that are not predictive enough even for diseases with relatively simple pathology.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="90eed218-b0d5-49cf-a209-934741f545c7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="90eed218-b0d5-49cf-a209-934741f545c7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sahdeo Prasad et al., “Serendipity in cancer drug discovery: Rational or coincidence?,”<em> Trends in Pharmacological Sciences</em>, June 1, 2016, Volume 37, Issue 6, pp. 435–50.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>It has long been hoped that new computational methods from the fields of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) would help scientists bring about a step change. Activity and investments by venture capital firms and pharmaceutical companies in these areas have grown substantially,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="48c105c9-4071-4328-9942-6151ce617684"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="48c105c9-4071-4328-9942-6151ce617684" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The R&D spending by the top 20 pharmaceutical companies to acquire data and analytics capabilities and technologies grew some threefold from 2016 to 2020 compared with the previous five-year period ($4.2 billion versus $1.5 billion). PitchBook Data, Inc. (data have not been reviewed by PitchBook analysts), as of November 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> and there have been some astonishing breakthroughs in the understanding of the causes of some indications, often as a result of leveraging new or greater volumes of data generated by whole-genome sequencing, high-throughput assays, and clinical or real-world evidence. Genetic insights, for example, helped identify PCSK9 as a hyperlipidemia modulator and have enabled new, tumor-agnostic oncology therapies. A better understanding of the role of immunological mechanisms has also introduced a new paradigm in cancer treatment, and similar concepts are now being applied to fibrosis, degenerative diseases, and more targeted immunotherapies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="af1649e5-4c79-48ec-8af4-c772831e44be"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="af1649e5-4c79-48ec-8af4-c772831e44be" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For example, CAR-T and TCR therapies are being engineered to harness the human immunological system in fighting disease, and bispecific antibodies are being adapted to more precisely modulate the inflammatory reactions of patients.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Such breakthroughs remain relatively rare, however. Despite expanding development pipelines,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3103ad6e-ba07-44c5-8916-13f10ab01a97"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3103ad6e-ba07-44c5-8916-13f10ab01a97" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The total number of nonbiosimilar, nonreformulated clinical-stage assets grew by 6 percent a year from 2012 to 2021. Informa Pharma Projects data, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> many pharmaceutical companies find themselves focusing on the same limited number of derisked areas and mechanisms of action in, for example, immuno-oncology. This “herding” reflects the challenges of advancing understanding of disease and hence of developing novel therapeutic approaches. The full promise of innovation from data, AI, and ML has not yet materialized.</p>
<p>It is increasingly evident that one of the main reasons for this is insufficient high-quality, interconnected human data that go beyond just genes and corresponding phenotypes—the  data needed by scientists to form concepts and hypotheses and by computing systems to uncover patterns too complex for scientists to understand. Only such high-quality human data would allow deployment of AI and ML, combined with human ingenuity, to unravel disease biology and open up new frontiers to prevention and cure. Here, therefore, we suggest a way of overcoming the data impediment and moving toward a systematic, nonreductionist approach to disease understanding and drug development: the establishment of trusted, large-scale platforms that collect and store the health data of volunteering participants. Importantly, such platforms would allow participants to make informed decisions about who could access and use their information to improve the understanding of disease.</p>
<h2>Data are the key to a leap in understanding disease</h2>
<p>Tech companies have transformed marketing through the use of computational models to analyze huge amounts of data about individual consumers and their buying behavior and then to deploy that information to adjust offers dynamically. Similarly, computational techniques and big data could transform drug R&D by shedding light on biological complexity to build holistic and reproducible disease models and develop more specific scalable therapies.</p>
<p>The power of computational science in drug discovery is becoming evidently clear. DeepMind’s AI algorithm, AlphaFold,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0c604bdc-5030-43ba-99e1-c473b74f4040"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0c604bdc-5030-43ba-99e1-c473b74f4040" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">John Jumper et al., “Highly accurate protein structure prediction with AlphaFold,” <em>Nature</em>, August 26, 2021, Volume 596, pp. 583–89.</span></span></span></a></span> has made progress predicting a protein’s structure from its amino acid sequence. Computational techniques, coupled with the ability to collect huge amounts of data on biological systems, have dramatically increased the accuracy of predictions on whether biological molecules will be efficacious, even without an understanding of the underlying biological concepts. For example, generative adversarial networks, an <em>in silico</em> methodology, can suggest molecules that might be effective against a disease, and these predictions can then be verified in vitro and in vivo. Yet until research sheds light on the fundamental mechanisms that explain if and why a drug candidate is efficacious and safe, drug discovery will remain an act of chance because so many candidates will turn out to be neither.</p>
<p>The interplay of AI and ML systems, insights guided by scientists, and the generation of evidence could change that model. The main barrier—according both to traditional pharmaceutical companies and new, technology-driven ones—is the lack of enough reliable, longitudinal, and interconnected health data.</p>
<p>Although there are reams of health data, much are of low quality because they are hard to validate and fragmented because they sit on many different platforms. Moreover, the quantity of these data makes them almost impossible for any purely human effort to categorize, clean, and label, so they are hard to access. Data privacy and security exacerbate the challenge. The hurdles are therefore twofold: to generate and collect sufficient good-quality data and to link or combine the data sets in a single, secure source suitable for ML and AI. In this respect, health data platforms could be a significant and exciting step forward.</p>
<h2>The role of health data platforms</h2>
<p>Even before the COVID-19 pandemic, individuals generated large amounts of health-relevant data from wearables, geolocation services, online symptom searches, and consumer-grade genetic testing. They also generated a lot of more structured data, such as insurance claims, pharmacy purchases, and electronic health records. In addition, many people take part in clinical or academic research, including research to collect high-quality multi-omics data, regarded as essential to progress in disease understanding and drug development.</p>
<p>Today, still more data are being generated as a result of the accelerated digitization of healthcare during the pandemic. And there is much wider acceptance—among patients, physicians, health systems, and regulators—of digital health in the form of telemedicine, wearables, and the virtual monitoring of clinical trials, for example. The sense of urgency that the pandemic unleashed has also encouraged more data sharing, which has improved the quality of data thanks to higher levels of scrutiny.</p>
<p>To be clear, there are many national and international health data initiatives to collect structured, high-quality data securely. For example, the 1+Million Genomes project involving 22 EU countries, the United Kingdom, and Norway aims to give access to more than one million sequenced genomes this year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4c5db7ff-4c52-471e-bb2e-8bff8bcc1dc2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4c5db7ff-4c52-471e-bb2e-8bff8bcc1dc2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“European ‘1+ Million Genomes’ initiative,” European Commission, last updated February 24, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> And Denmark has a long tradition of collecting data from records of treatment, medicine, and diagnosis that can be linked for every citizen.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="536f29f5-c488-4bd8-b7f9-f1cd563a7ed8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="536f29f5-c488-4bd8-b7f9-f1cd563a7ed8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Healthcare data,” Healthcare Denmark.</span></span></span></a></span> Health data companies are also accumulating and combining existing data from patient records and real-world evidence. Notwithstanding, data gaps remain. Relatively little omics data beyond the genome is collected—data on the expressome, proteome, or microbiome, for example (Exhibit 1). Longitudinal data will be key too—data from numerous sources, including social media and wearables, and from different points in time to capture early symptoms and manifestation of diseases and comorbidities. This can not only help identify individual novel molecular targets but also—as important and perhaps a bigger challenge—help to understand all disease-related signals and hence the optimal therapeutic approach. (Ultimately, greater depth of data on any individual might be more important than data on an ever-greater number of individuals.)</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/better%20data%20for%20better%20therapies%20the%20case%20for%20building%20health%20data%20platforms/svgz-dataenableddiseaseunderstanding-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="A range of omics data beyond genomics, collectively known as omics, is a key to progress in drug development." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/better%20data%20for%20better%20therapies%20the%20case%20for%20building%20health%20data%20platforms/svgz-dataenableddiseaseunderstanding-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Yet the foundations exist for what could be a hugely valuable homogenous, longitudinal, quantitative, and qualitative data-vault, <em>if</em> existing and new data could be linked and shared with a respect for privacy; hence the requirement for secure, trusted, data platforms where participants would agree to deposit their health data on the understanding they would receive a copy of each recorded data point. That would help them make informed decisions about giving third parties, such as public or private pharmaceutical researchers, the right to access and use this information.</p>
<p>Privacy and security will of course be a challenge. But technologies, such as blockchain, that enable secure data transactions and smart contracts are fast maturing. What’s more, unlike many of today’s data-based applications, which require users to give blanket approval for the use of their data, newer technologies could give participants the choice to approve or deny each data-sharing request. Both developments make sharing data more attractive.</p>
<p>Several initiatives have met with early success. The Swiss nonprofit MIDATA,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="80c04538-62de-4d26-abd7-fda66d60c88b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="80c04538-62de-4d26-abd7-fda66d60c88b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Stefano Napolitano and Dominik Steiger, “Health data ecosystems of the future need trust and citizen inclusion,” in Thomas Brenzikofer et al. editors, <em>Shaping the Health Data Future—the Day One Scenarios</em>, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> for example, is a platform where people can give research projects access to their data. Estonia aggregates the electronic health records of all its citizens, using blockchain to make them secure and accessible with a simple electronic ID card.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f1689dc0-1835-4d36-a86a-60070035b287"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f1689dc0-1835-4d36-a86a-60070035b287" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Dirk Draheim et al., <em>Ten years of the e-health system in Estonia</em>, Proceedings of the 3rd International Workshop on (Meta) Modelling for Healthcare Systems, Bergen, Norway, June 13, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> To fully unlock opportunities for systematic disease understanding, initiatives will need to be on a much larger scale, however.</p>
<h2>The benefits of secure health data platforms</h2>
<p>The potential benefits of large-scale data platforms are far-reaching.</p>
<p>First, by amassing and monitoring data from both healthy people and those in the early and later stages of disease, these platforms could enable clinicians to distinguish more clearly between disease states and therefore to diagnose or even predict and preempt a disease with the help of a more precise progression taxonomy.</p>
<p>Second, good data would promote a less reductionist approach to understanding disease biology and generating hypotheses for treating previously untreatable conditions, such as dementia, or to addressing the still unmet needs of patients with treatable diseases: drug-resistant disease variants or complications, for example.</p>
<p>Finally, harnessing large-scale human health platforms could broaden the scope of medical innovation by shedding light on how factors (such as behavior, nutrition, surgery, or medical devices) beyond prescribed drugs could be used and sequenced to treat individual patients in more holistic and sustainable ways.</p>
<p>The overall result could be a faster, less risky (that is, more predictive) R&D process in which the knowledge and skills of scientists, combined with in silico and in vitro tests, would drive faster cycles for generating and validating ideas. Higher-quality and more complete real-world evidence could enrich this process further by complementing and extending the health data platform, creating the potential for further insights and unleashing a self-propelling loop of generating evidence and improving the management of disease.</p>
<h2>The value at stake: An example from neurology</h2>
<p>Certain kinds of data will be relevant for understanding many diseases. But a deep understanding of specific ones—an understanding deep enough to uncover actionable therapeutic insights—would probably require patient data related to specific diseases. Building platforms with sufficient data to cover all diseases would
still therefore appear to be a dream. A more feasible starting point would be a disease-specific platform.</p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The cost of a better understanding of disease</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>The cost of building</strong> a health data platform depends upon the amount of data it includes. While collecting and combining existing historic data can be much cheaper, we chose to concentrate on the generation of new nonmainstream data for which current tests or examinations exist and the results can be directly and unambiguously linked to disease-relevant states of human cells or organs. Our analysis therefore reflects the cost of generating the participants’ genomics data (which is relatively inexpensive and for which links with some diseases are established), transcriptomics and metabolomics data—data that can impart information on which genes are actively expressed and the basic biochemical characteristics of a given tissue state.</p>
<p>In our opinion, other branches of omics, such as epigenomics and proteomics, provide a lower insight-to-cost ratio because they are not yet mature enough to offer disease-specific insights—although this will probably change with time and scale—while being still comparably expensive. Our analysis also includes the costs of conducting various scans and assessments, such as function and cognition tests, the measurement of disease-specific biomarkers, and imaging, such as CT or PET scans.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0ab47332-f3fb-43f9-b0a6-f6eab1bddfc6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0ab47332-f3fb-43f9-b0a6-f6eab1bddfc6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">CT or PET scans would only be carried out for diagnostic purposes. Scans not potentially detrimental to health could be carried out on healthy participants.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>These data can be readily complemented with existing data from health records or linked to other initiatives capturing real-world evidence.</p>
<p>Our analysis (on the basis of today’s costs) suggests that some $27,200 per person could be required to collect the relevant data. At least one million participants would be needed, bringing the cost to $27.2 billion. To distinguish between healthy and diseased states, the participants would include healthy people and those diagnosed with a relevant neurological disease. The analysis also assumes that at least 50 patients per neurological health condition would have to participate to gather enough data to deepen understanding of its biology and that participants with rare diseases (a prevalence of five per 100,000 people) and common diseases would both be included.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8668d5e5-8423-4c59-935f-1efd7581924e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8668d5e5-8423-4c59-935f-1efd7581924e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">This is the minimum value of a range of national definitions of rare disorders and diseases, ranging from five to 80 per 100,000. See Charlotte Gueydan et al., “Estimating cumulative point prevalence of rare diseases: Analysis of the Orphanet database,” <em>European Journal of Human Genetics</em>, September 16, 2019, Volume 28, pp. 165–73. In the European Union, rare diseases are defined as conditions with a prevalence of not more than 50 per 100,000. See Regulation number 141/2000 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 December 1999 on orphan medicinal products.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>In this way, it would be possible to analyze some 60 percent of reported disorders with prevalence data disclosed by the Orphanet database.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e4bb8e0b-7a4d-4234-ae12-26a7ea3789ec"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e4bb8e0b-7a4d-4234-ae12-26a7ea3789ec" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Orphanet, a European database for rare diseases, is managed by consortium of academic establishments representing 40 countries.</span></span></span></a></span> This assumes, however, that our current taxonomy of diseases correctly represents the pathophysiology and that one disease unit, in most cases, corresponds to a uniform group of root causes. With more in-depth characterization, we might uncover new subindications requiring an expanded data set. The model assumes that data collection costs will decline in line with Moore’s law, as they have for the Human Genome Project.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f4ac917c-8744-4b50-a09c-b466cc0e535e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f4ac917c-8744-4b50-a09c-b466cc0e535e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“The cost of sequencing a human genome,” National Human Genome Research Institute. </span></span></span></a></span> The model does not take into account inflation, since any increase or decrease would also apply to benefits accrued.</p>
<p>Let’s put this platform’s $27.2 billion cost into perspective: it is 5.2 times greater than that of the Human Genome Project,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="37702f03-7cde-44ca-8e3f-b6c717d1be3f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="37702f03-7cde-44ca-8e3f-b6c717d1be3f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The US contribution to the Human Genome Project in the 2020 fiscal year is estimated at around $5.2 billion (based on applying the inflation rate from 1991 to 2020). Costs were stated as $2.7 billion in the 1991 fiscal year. See “Human genome project FAQ,” National Human Genome Research Institute.</span></span></span></a></span> around 2.7 times greater than annual funding from the US National Institutes of Health for academic basic research in neurology,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c1f1daf4-3fec-4925-a8b5-1418b93fe268"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c1f1daf4-3fec-4925-a8b5-1418b93fe268" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Funding in 2020 for US academic basic research related to neuroscience was stated to be $10.1 billion. See “Estimates of funding for various research, condition, and disease categories (RCDC),” National Institutes of Health, June 25, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> and around 1.5 times greater than the global biopharmaceutical industry’s estimated annual spending on neurology R&D. Although these costs will be amortized as benefits accrue, it will take time to translate new insights into new therapies and, potentially, new business models.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Costs are a significant consideration. To illustrate the costs of building such a platform, we looked at neurology—an area of high unmet need. We estimate that it would cost around $27 billion to build a platform with relevant omics measurement data for some one million people (an estimated minimum for systematic and scalable drug discovery), as well as imaging data and qualitative assessments, such as functional or cognitive tests (Exhibit 2). The $27 billion would not include the cost of IT infrastructure, of enrolling participants, or of complementing the generated data with existing data from health records or real-world evidence—both of which are, in comparison, relatively affordable, especially if we assume greater digitization and interoperability of health systems in the future. (The sidebar, “The cost of a better understanding of disease,” explains the calculation in more detail.)</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/better%20data%20for%20better%20therapies%20the%20case%20for%20building%20health%20data%20platforms/svgz-dataenableddiseaseunderstanding-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="A health data platform for neurology would cost more than $27 billion." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/better%20data%20for%20better%20therapies%20the%20case%20for%20building%20health%20data%20platforms/svgz-dataenableddiseaseunderstanding-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The sum is large—1.5 times greater than the estimated amount the global biopharmaceutical industry spends each year on neurology R&D, for example.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="27d6495b-a9cd-4c3b-9e58-3cda8852865a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="27d6495b-a9cd-4c3b-9e58-3cda8852865a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Calculated by applying the share of the cost of central nervous system-related clinical trials of all clinical trials across all therapeutic areas in 2020 (about 9 percent) and comparing that with the cost of the global biopharmaceutical industry’s R&D spending (including research, discovery, and preclinical) in 2020. These costs amounted to some $200 billion, a figure based on reported financials of public companies and on Evaluate estimates for notable private ones. Hence, estimated industry-wide neurology-related R&D costs reached about $18 billion in 2020. EvaluatePharma, March 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> However, we estimate that such a platform could have a direct, positive economic impact of some $25 billion a year within 20 to 25 years, even assuming relatively modest progress in capturing the potential for innovation.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d948db62-f897-4d33-b60b-ac3b092abff7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d948db62-f897-4d33-b60b-ac3b092abff7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more, see<em> <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/prioritizing-health-a-prescription-for-prosperity"><em>Prioritizing health: A prescription for prosperity</em>, July 8, 2020</a></em>; <em><a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/the-bio-revolution-innovations-transforming-economies-societies-and-our-lives">The Bio Revolution: Innovations transforming economies, societies, and our lives</a></em>, May 13, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Exhibit 3 shows that the biggest opportunity lies in helping people to live longer, healthier lives (with a resulting annual GDP increase of $12.3 billion).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/better%20data%20for%20better%20therapies%20the%20case%20for%20building%20health%20data%20platforms/svgz-dataenableddiseaseunderstanding-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="A citizen health data platform for neurology could deliver annual benefits of around $25 billion." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/better%20data%20for%20better%20therapies%20the%20case%20for%20building%20health%20data%20platforms/svgz-dataenableddiseaseunderstanding-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The second-biggest opportunity lies in the discovery and development of novel therapeutics for neurological diseases currently untreatable because the underlying biology isn’t understood. If novel therapies removed just 1 percent of the global disease burden associated with neurological disorders by around 2045, the economic impact would be striking: an estimated $9.7 billion a year.</p>
<p>A third opportunity (of $2.8 billion) lies in more efficient R&D: the identification of additional promising drug candidates, the successful repurposing of drugs, better patient stratification in clinical trials, and less animal testing (which is reported to be a weak indicator of clinical outcomes and is due to be banned by the US Environmental Protection Agency by 2035).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="537a9b21-bea9-4537-be0d-38d4f59854e5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="537a9b21-bea9-4537-be0d-38d4f59854e5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Administrator Wheeler signs memo to reduce animal testing, awards $4.25 million to advance research on alternative methods to animal testing,” US Environmental Protection Agency, September 10, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Gains of such magnitude could eventually amortize the initial costs many times over. Some 90 percent of the 20,000 or so existing proteins have not been touched by pharmacology—a huge potential value pool. Add in improved and novel modalities, and the scientific breakthroughs for many disease-related proteins once considered undruggable could be dramatic.</p>
<h2>Moving toward health data platforms and a data-driven understanding of disease</h2>
<p>The first step toward building health data platforms of the type described here would be to prove the concept by establishing core principles and demonstrating the benefits. There are two possible ways of proceeding. The first would be to coordinate and link existing country-level initiatives to establish standards and platforms. The other would be to set up a pilot in an area of high unmet need, such as dementia. To date, neurological and mental-health disorders have proved extremely challenging to treat, and that has limited R&D efforts in these fields. This makes them a good testing ground, given the societal and health burden they impose, though we are not suggesting the data on all new platforms would have to be as comprehensive (and hence as costly) as the neurological example outlined here. There is reason to believe smaller projects could still deliver significant benefits if well designed.</p>
<p>We also recognize the challenges of building health data platforms—defining a clear and holistic approach on data ownership and usage, data privacy and security, and the potential for monetization, for example. But such challenges can be addressed with the help of a range of organizations, including pharmaceutical and biotech companies, tech giants, governments, foundations, and other nongovernmental organizations. Many of the data collection initiatives afoot have been directed by public, nonprofit, and public–private bodies. But the most effective approaches will probably be collaborative, combining the different strengths of different stakeholders, harnessing their credibility, resources, societal reach, and technological know-how. Researchers too have a part to play, since they and their organizations must start adjusting their approach to drug discovery, moving away from a reductionist approach by harnessing all available data. To this end, interdisciplinary teams will have to be formed, drawing on the power of both science and computational techniques. It’s time to start putting our health data to work for a better understanding of disease.</p>
<hr>
<p>Breakthroughs in the biological sciences and advances in computing—particularly AI and ML—are accelerating progress at each stage of the pharmaceutical R&D value chain. Yet the coming of a new era of biopharmaceutical innovation arguably requires making much more progress at the very first step in that chain—the understanding of disease. Given the multifactorial nature of disease biology, AI and ML will be needed to help scientists systematically improve that understanding by uncovering the patterns that explain disease. And that in turn will depend upon access to better data that health data platforms could provide. They could be key to ushering in an era of exponential innovation in healthcare.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Matthias Evers</strong> is a senior partner in McKinsey’s Hamburg office, <strong><a href="/our-people/lucy-perez">Lucy Pérez</a> </strong>is a senior partner in the Boston office, <strong>Lucas Robke</strong> is a consultant in the Düsseldorf office, and <strong>Katarzyna Smietana </strong>is a senior knowledge expert and associate partner in the Wroclaw office.</p>

data for better therapies: The case for building health data platforms"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Better therapies need better data: The case for building health-data understanding of disease."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-04-15T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe past decade\u003c/strong\u003e has seen an important and, for many patients, a life-changing rise in the number of innovative new drugs reaching the market to treat diseases such as multiple sclerosis, malaria, and subtypes of certain cancers (such as melanoma or leukemia). In the United States, the Food and Drug Administration approved an average of 41 new molecular entities (including biologic license applications) each year from 2011 to 2020\u0026mdash;almost double the number in the previous decade.[[Footnote 1]] Despite the immense costs of such achievements,[[Footnote 2]] biopharmaceutical researchers have not yet uncovered a universal, systematic approach to generate many more breakthroughs or predict which interventions will work for which patients.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eA major barrier is the daunting challenge of understanding the multifactorial nature of many diseases coupled with the vast set of variables in therapy design. Very few diseases, such as cystic fibrosis, are linked to variants in single genes. Drug development therefore tends to rely on a reductionist, hypothesis-driven approach that narrows the focus to individual cell types or pathways. Focused assays often based on partial information or informed by animal models that never perfectly reflect human disease then attempt to identify single molecules that will benefit patients. Inevitably, that approach can be both slow and prone to bias, and most breakthroughs are serendipitous rather than systematic, as companies are largely relying on imperfect preclinical models that are not predictive enough even for diseases with relatively simple pathology.[[Footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt has long been hoped that new computational methods from the fields of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) would help scientists bring about a step change. Activity and investments by venture capital firms and pharmaceutical companies in these areas have grown substantially,[[Footnote 4]] and there have been some astonishing breakthroughs in the understanding of the causes of some indications, often as a result of leveraging new or greater volumes of data generated by whole-genome sequencing, high-throughput assays, and clinical or real-world evidence. Genetic insights, for example, helped identify PCSK9 as a hyperlipidemia modulator and have enabled new, tumor-agnostic oncology therapies. A better understanding of the role of immunological mechanisms has also introduced a new paradigm in cancer treatment, and similar concepts are now being applied to fibrosis, degenerative diseases, and more targeted immunotherapies.[[Footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSuch breakthroughs remain relatively rare, however. Despite expanding development pipelines,[[Footnote 6]] many pharmaceutical companies find themselves focusing on the same limited number of derisked areas and mechanisms of action in, for example, immuno-oncology. This \u0026ldquo;herding\u0026rdquo; reflects the challenges of advancing understanding of disease and hence of developing novel therapeutic approaches. The full promise of innovation from data, AI, and ML has not yet materialized.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt is increasingly evident that one of the main reasons for this is insufficient high-quality, interconnected human data that go beyond just genes and corresponding phenotypes\u0026mdash;the  data needed by scientists to form concepts and hypotheses and by computing systems to uncover patterns too complex for scientists to understand. Only such high-quality human data would allow deployment of AI and ML, combined with human ingenuity, to unravel disease biology and open up new frontiers to prevention and cure. Here, therefore, we suggest a way of overcoming the data impediment and moving toward a systematic, nonreductionist approach to disease understanding and drug development: the establishment of trusted, large-scale platforms that collect and store the health data of volunteering participants. Importantly, such platforms would allow participants to make informed decisions about who could access and use their information to improve the understanding of disease.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eData are the key to a leap in understanding disease\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTech companies have transformed marketing through the use of computational models to analyze huge amounts of data about individual consumers and their buying behavior and then to deploy that information to adjust offers dynamically. Similarly, computational techniques and big data could transform drug R\u0026amp;D by shedding light on biological complexity to build holistic and reproducible disease models and develop more specific scalable therapies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe power of computational science in drug discovery is becoming evidently clear. DeepMind\u0026rsquo;s AI algorithm, AlphaFold,[[Footnote 7]] has made progress predicting a protein\u0026rsquo;s structure from its amino acid sequence. Computational techniques, coupled with the ability to collect huge amounts of data on biological systems, have dramatically increased the accuracy of predictions on whether biological molecules will be efficacious, even without an understanding of the underlying biological concepts. For example, generative adversarial networks, an \u003cem\u003ein silico\u003c/em\u003e methodology, can suggest molecules that might be effective against a disease, and these predictions can then be verified in vitro and in vivo. Yet until research sheds light on the fundamental mechanisms that explain if and why a drug candidate is efficacious and safe, drug discovery will remain an act of chance because so many candidates will turn out to be neither.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe interplay of AI and ML systems, insights guided by scientists, and the generation of evidence could change that model. The main barrier\u0026mdash;according both to traditional pharmaceutical companies and new, technology-driven ones\u0026mdash;is the lack of enough reliable, longitudinal, and interconnected health data.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough there are reams of health data, much are of low quality because they are hard to validate and fragmented because they sit on many different platforms. Moreover, the quantity of these data makes them almost impossible for any purely human effort to categorize, clean, and label, so they are hard to access. Data privacy and security exacerbate the challenge. The hurdles are therefore twofold: to generate and collect sufficient good-quality data and to link or combine the data sets in a single, secure source suitable for ML and AI. In this respect, health data platforms could be a significant and exciting step forward.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe role of health data platforms\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEven before the COVID-19 pandemic, individuals generated large amounts of health-relevant data from wearables, geolocation services, online symptom searches, and consumer-grade genetic testing. They also generated a lot of more structured data, such as insurance claims, pharmacy purchases, and electronic health records. In addition, many people take part in clinical or academic research, including research to collect high-quality multi-omics data, regarded as essential to progress in disease understanding and drug development.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eToday, still more data are being generated as a result of the accelerated digitization of healthcare during the pandemic. And there is much wider acceptance\u0026mdash;among patients, physicians, health systems, and regulators\u0026mdash;of digital health in the form of telemedicine, wearables, and the virtual monitoring of clinical trials, for example. The sense of urgency that the pandemic unleashed has also encouraged more data sharing, which has improved the quality of data thanks to higher levels of scrutiny.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo be clear, there are many national and international health data initiatives to collect structured, high-quality data securely. For example, the 1+Million Genomes project involving 22 EU countries, the United Kingdom, and Norway aims to give access to more than one million sequenced genomes this year.[[Footnote 8]] And Denmark has a long tradition of collecting data from records of treatment, medicine, and diagnosis that can be linked for every citizen.[[Footnote 9]] Health data companies are also accumulating and combining existing data from patient records and real-world evidence. Notwithstanding, data gaps remain. Relatively little omics data beyond the genome is collected\u0026mdash;data on the expressome, proteome, or microbiome, for example (Exhibit\u0026nbsp;1). Longitudinal data will be key too\u0026mdash;data from numerous sources, including social media and wearables, and from different points in time to capture early symptoms and manifestation of diseases and comorbidities. This can not only help identify individual novel molecular targets but also\u0026mdash;as important and perhaps a bigger challenge\u0026mdash;help to understand all disease-related signals and hence the optimal therapeutic approach. (Ultimately, greater depth of data on any individual might be more important than data on an ever-greater number of individuals.)\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eYet the foundations exist for what could be a hugely valuable homogenous, longitudinal, quantitative, and qualitative data-vault, \u003cem\u003eif\u003c/em\u003e existing and new data could be linked and shared with a respect for privacy; hence the requirement for secure, trusted, data platforms where participants would agree to deposit their health data on the understanding they would receive a copy of each recorded data point. That would help them make informed decisions about giving third parties, such as public or private pharmaceutical researchers, the right to access and use this information.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePrivacy and security will of course be a challenge. But technologies, such as blockchain, that enable secure data transactions and smart contracts are fast maturing. What\u0026rsquo;s more, unlike many of today\u0026rsquo;s data-based applications, which require users to give blanket approval for the use of their data, newer technologies could give participants the choice to approve or deny each data-sharing request. Both developments make sharing data more attractive.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeveral initiatives have met with early success. The Swiss nonprofit MIDATA,[[Footnote 10]] for example, is a platform where people can give research projects access to their data. Estonia aggregates the electronic health records of all its citizens, using blockchain to make them secure and accessible with a simple electronic ID card.[[Footnote 11]] To fully unlock opportunities for systematic disease understanding, initiatives will need to be on a much larger scale, however.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe benefits of secure health data platforms\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe potential benefits of large-scale data platforms are far-reaching.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirst, by amassing and monitoring data from both healthy people and those in the early and later stages of disease, these platforms could enable clinicians to distinguish more clearly between disease states and therefore to diagnose or even predict and preempt a disease with the help of a more precise progression taxonomy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSecond, good data would promote a less reductionist approach to understanding disease biology and generating hypotheses for treating previously untreatable conditions, such as dementia, or to addressing the still unmet needs of patients with treatable diseases: drug-resistant disease variants or complications, for example.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, harnessing large-scale human health platforms could broaden the scope of medical innovation by shedding light on how factors (such as behavior, nutrition, surgery, or medical devices) beyond prescribed drugs could be used and sequenced to treat individual patients in more holistic and sustainable ways.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe overall result could be a faster, less risky (that is, more predictive) R\u0026amp;D process in which the knowledge and skills of scientists, combined with in silico and in vitro tests, would drive faster cycles for generating and validating ideas. Higher-quality and more complete real-world evidence could enrich this process further by complementing and extending the health data platform, creating the potential for further insights and unleashing a self-propelling loop of generating evidence and improving the management of disease.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe value at stake: An example from neurology\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCertain kinds of data will be relevant for understanding many diseases. But a deep understanding of specific ones\u0026mdash;an understanding deep enough to uncover actionable therapeutic insights\u0026mdash;would probably require patient data related to specific diseases. Building platforms with sufficient data to cover all diseases would\nstill therefore appear to be a dream. A more feasible starting point would be a disease-specific platform.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eCosts are a significant consideration. To illustrate the costs of building such a platform, we looked at neurology\u0026mdash;an area of high unmet need. We estimate that it would cost around $27 billion to build a platform with relevant omics measurement data for some one million people (an estimated minimum for systematic and scalable drug discovery), as well as imaging data and qualitative assessments, such as functional or cognitive tests (Exhibit 2). The $27 billion would not include the cost of IT infrastructure, of enrolling participants, or of complementing the generated data with existing data from health records or real-world evidence\u0026mdash;both of which are, in comparison, relatively affordable, especially if we assume greater digitization and interoperability of health systems in the future. (The sidebar, \u0026ldquo;The cost of a better understanding of disease,\u0026rdquo; explains the calculation in more detail.)\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe sum is large\u0026mdash;1.5 times greater than the estimated amount the global biopharmaceutical industry spends each year on neurology R\u0026amp;D, for example.[[Footnote 12]] However, we estimate that such a platform could have a direct, positive economic impact of some $25 billion a year within 20 to 25\u0026nbsp;years, even assuming relatively modest progress in capturing the potential for innovation.[[Footnote 13]] Exhibit 3 shows that the biggest opportunity lies in helping people to live longer, healthier lives (with a resulting annual GDP increase of $12.3 billion).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe second-biggest opportunity lies in the discovery and development of novel therapeutics for neurological diseases currently untreatable because the underlying biology isn\u0026rsquo;t understood. If novel therapies removed just 1 percent of the global disease burden associated with neurological disorders by around 2045, the economic impact would be striking: an estimated $9.7 billion a year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA third opportunity (of $2.8 billion) lies in more efficient R\u0026amp;D: the identification of additional promising drug candidates, the successful repurposing of drugs, better patient stratification in clinical trials, and less animal testing (which is reported to be a weak indicator of clinical outcomes and is due to be banned by the US Environmental Protection Agency by 2035).[[Footnote 14]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGains of such magnitude could eventually amortize the initial costs many times over. Some 90 percent of the 20,000 or so existing proteins have not been touched by pharmacology\u0026mdash;a huge potential value pool. Add in improved and novel modalities, and the scientific breakthroughs for many disease-related proteins once considered undruggable could be dramatic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eMoving toward health data platforms and a data-driven understanding of disease\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe first step toward building health data platforms of the type described here would be to prove the concept by establishing core principles and demonstrating the benefits. There are two possible ways of proceeding. The first would be to coordinate and link existing country-level initiatives to establish standards and platforms. The other would be to set up a pilot in an area of high unmet need, such as dementia. To date, neurological and mental-health disorders have proved extremely challenging to treat, and that has limited R\u0026amp;D efforts in these fields. This makes them a good testing ground, given the societal and health burden they impose, though we are not suggesting the data on all new platforms would have to be as comprehensive (and hence as costly) as the neurological example outlined here. There is reason to believe smaller projects could still deliver significant benefits if well designed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe also recognize the challenges of building health data platforms\u0026mdash;defining a clear and holistic approach on data ownership and usage, data privacy and security, and the potential for monetization, for example. But such challenges can be addressed with the help of a range of organizations, including pharmaceutical and biotech companies, tech giants, governments, foundations, and other nongovernmental organizations. Many of the data collection initiatives afoot have been directed by public, nonprofit, and public\u0026ndash;private bodies. But the most effective approaches will probably be collaborative, combining the different strengths of different stakeholders, harnessing their credibility, resources, societal reach, and technological know-how. Researchers too have a part to play, since they and their organizations must start adjusting their approach to drug discovery, moving away from a reductionist approach by harnessing all available data. To this end, interdisciplinary teams will have to be formed, drawing on the power of both science and computational techniques. It\u0026rsquo;s time to start putting our health data to work for a better understanding of disease.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBreakthroughs in the biological sciences and advances in computing\u0026mdash;particularly AI and ML\u0026mdash;are accelerating progress at each stage of the pharmaceutical R\u0026amp;D value chain. Yet the coming of a new era of biopharmaceutical innovation arguably requires making much more progress at the very first step in that chain\u0026mdash;the understanding of disease. Given the multifactorial nature of disease biology, AI and ML will be needed to help scientists systematically improve that understanding by uncovering the patterns that explain disease. And that in turn will depend upon access to better data that health data platforms could provide. They could be key to ushering in an era of exponential innovation in healthcare.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-04-15T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAsher Mullard, \u0026ldquo;2020 FDA drug approvals,\u0026rdquo; current on your favorite topics"}}}]},"articlesidebar":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"1"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe cost of building\u003c/strong\u003e a health data platform depends upon the amount of data it includes. While collecting and combining existing historic data can be much cheaper, we chose to concentrate on the generation of new nonmainstream data for which current tests or examinations exist and the results can be directly and unambiguously linked to disease-relevant states of human cells or organs. Our analysis therefore reflects the cost of generating the participants\u0026rsquo; genomics data (which is relatively inexpensive and for which links with some diseases are established), transcriptomics and metabolomics data\u0026mdash;data that can impart information on which genes are actively expressed and the basic biochemical characteristics of a given tissue state.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn our opinion, other branches of omics, such as epigenomics and proteomics, provide a lower insight-to-cost ratio because they are not yet mature enough to offer disease-specific insights\u0026mdash;although this will probably change with time and scale\u0026mdash;while being still comparably expensive. Our analysis also includes the costs of conducting various scans and assessments, such as function and cognition tests, the measurement of disease-specific biomarkers, and imaging, such as CT or PET scans.[[Footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese data can be readily complemented with existing data from health records or linked to other initiatives capturing real-world evidence.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur analysis (on the basis of today\u0026rsquo;s costs) suggests that some $27,200 per person could be required to collect the relevant data. At least one million participants would be needed, bringing the cost to $27.2 billion. To distinguish between healthy and diseased states, the participants would include healthy people and those diagnosed with a relevant neurological disease. The analysis also assumes that at least 50 patients per neurological health condition would have to participate to gather enough data to deepen understanding of its biology and that participants with rare diseases (a prevalence of five per 100,000 people) and common diseases would both be included.[[Footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this way, it would be possible to analyze some 60 percent of reported disorders with prevalence data disclosed by the Orphanet database.[[Footnote 3]] This assumes, however, that our current taxonomy of diseases correctly represents the pathophysiology and that one disease unit, in most cases, corresponds to a uniform group of root causes. With more in-depth characterization, we might uncover new subindications requiring an expanded data set. The model assumes that data collection costs will decline in line with Moore\u0026rsquo;s law, as they have for the Human Genome Project.[[Footnote 4]] The model does not take into account inflation, since any increase or decrease would also apply to benefits accrued.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet\u0026rsquo;s put this platform\u0026rsquo;s $27.2 billion cost into perspective: it is 5.2 times greater than that of the Human Genome Project,[[Footnote 5]] around 2.7 times greater than annual funding from the US National Institutes of Health for academic basic research in neurology,[[Footnote 6]] and around 1.5 times greater than the global biopharmaceutical industry\u0026rsquo;s estimated annual spending on neurology R\u0026amp;D. Although these costs will be amortized as benefits accrue, it will take time to translate new insights into new therapies and, potentially, new business models.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The cost of a better understanding of disease"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCT or PET scans would only be carried out for diagnostic purposes. Scans not potentially detrimental to health could be carried out on healthy participants.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThis is the minimum value of a range of national definitions of rare disorders and diseases, ranging from five to 80 per 100,000. See Charlotte Gueydan et al., \u0026ldquo;Estimating cumulative point prevalence of rare diseases: Analysis of the Orphanet database,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eEuropean Journal of Human Genetics\u003c/em\u003e, September 16, 2019, Volume 28, pp. 165\u0026ndash;73. In the European Union, rare diseases are defined as conditions with a prevalence of not more than 50 per 100,000. See Regulation number 141/2000 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 December 1999 on orphan medicinal products.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOrphanet, a European database for rare diseases, is managed by consortium of academic establishments representing 40 countries.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;The cost of sequencing a human genome,\u0026rdquo; National Human Genome Research Institute. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe US contribution to the Human Genome Project in the 2020 fiscal year is estimated at around $5.2 billion (based on applying the inflation rate from 1991 to 2020). Costs were stated as $2.7 billion in the 1991 fiscal year. See \u0026ldquo;Human genome project FAQ,\u0026rdquo; National Human Genome Research Institute.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFunding in 2020 for US academic basic research related to neuroscience was stated to be $10.1 billion. See \u0026ldquo;Estimates of funding for various research, condition, and disease categories (RCDC),\u0026rdquo; National Institutes of Health, June 25,
